awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Understanding and Ccontrolling Fatigue in Photo-Responsive MOFs: Characterizing Photochromic Transformations in Single Crystals
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
In this project funded by the Solid-State Materials Chemistry program of the Division of Materials Research, the research team is developing crystalline porous materials that are activated by UV light. The photo-active chemical groups change shape when exposed to light. These light-driven transformations cause the pores (holes) and channels of the crystalline frameworks to change shape leading to materials capable of selectively absorbing or releasing guest molecules, for example pharmaceutical drugs, but only when exposed to the proper wavelength of light. In addition to advancing our understanding of the fundamental photochemistry that occurs in these novel materials, the research establishes design principles to understand and ultimately control and prevent fatigue (failure) in a variety of photo-responsive materials. The education and outreach activities bring crystallography and X-ray science into U.S. classrooms through the continued development of an X-ray science course for advanced undergraduate and graduate students. The educational projects, including a nation-wide crystal growing competition, bring concepts of crystals and light to K-12 classrooms through the development of hands-on experiments and curricular development for teachers and students.

Technical Abstract:
This research focuses on identifying and understanding the root causes of fatigue in photochromic materials with the ultimate goal of developing design principles to control fatigue in any photo-responsive system. The primary objective is developing a detailed molecular level understanding of the photochemistry occurring within diarylethene-based materials, an exciting niche in the nascent field of photo-responsive metal-organic frameworks.  Specific aims of the research include: (1) the synthesis and characterization of new diarylethene-based photoswitchable linkers and metal-organic frameworks prepared from these linkers, (2) quantifying the photophysics of photochromic molecules in crystalline environments using spectroscopic and diffraction methods to determine reaction energetics and limitations, (3) determining the factors and triggers that govern fatigue in these materials, (4) developing new techniques to assess the distribution of guest species within the metal-organic framework nanopores and determining their impact on the photophysical properties of the crystalline frameworks, (5) using the knowledge gained to rationally design and engineer advanced photochromic materials with enhanced properties, namely improved resistance to fatigue. The primary research tools include traditional and in situ single crystal X-ray diffraction (photo-crystallography), steady-state and time-resolved absorption spectroscopy/microscopy, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), mass spectrometry, thermogravimetric analysis, and computational modeling.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Combining the photo-responsive properties of diarylethenes with metal-organic frameworks will transform these traditionally passive materials into active materials that change their chemical or electronic properties in response to light stimulus.However, given the conformational flexibility of these molecules, the creation of photo-responsive crystals 'by design' remains an incredibly difficult scientific challenge. The research conducted through this award led to the creation of several new diarylethene molecules with enhanced properties, including highly stable ring-open and ring-closed forms and the abiltiy to readily form crystalline materials.

The impact of crystal packing forces on the geometry of the diarylethene in the lattice cannot be understated. Unfortunately with today's understanding and technology, it is for all intents and purposes impossible to predict apriori the structure of a multi-component diarylethene crystal. To that end, a new non-vector-based parameterization of the diarylthethenes was developed using the structures produced under this award. This parameterization lays the foundation for rapidly and unambigiously assessing the diarylethene isomer within a crystal lattice. This is a critical first step to determining any conserved interactions which ultimately determine which isomer is stabilized in a given crystal system. 

The award also funded new developments in in situ X-ray diffraction experiments. A novel Environmental Control Cell was designed and fabricated that allows researchers to collect diffraction data on single crystals under 'real world' conditions. It is anticipated that the design principles and experimental techniques developed through this research program will be used to reliably produce diarylethene-based photoswitchable crystals and ultimately be extended to other photochromic systems.

Broder Impacts:

Reducing our dependence on non-renewable resources requires next-generation materials be designed and engineered with an emphasis on sustainability in terms of manufacturing, useful lifetime, and eventual disposal.  Exposing graduate and undergraduate researchers to projects which focus on the understanding and optimization of longevity and efficiency in modern materials conveys the importance of experiments beyond traditional materials optimization.  Publishing this research in high impact journals demonstrates the importance of these principles to the larger scientific community.

The education and outreach activities brought crystallography and X-ray science into U.S. classrooms through the continued development of an X-ray science course for advanced undergraduate and graduate students and a nation-wide crystal growing competition for students and teachers in grades K-12. A 'Crystal Engineering' lab taught undergraduates how to think about solid-state interactions in order to 'design' new crystalline lattices. The experiments performed by undergraduates were reported in three peer-reviewed publications in which the lab partners were all co-authors on the manuscripts!

Starting in 2014, the US Crystal Growing Competition is a yearly event that provides students, educators, and parents across the country the opportunity to participate in a fun and exciting hands-on STEM-based competition. The object of the contest is to grow the largest and highest quality single crystal of alum in 5 weeks with 100 grams of alum. Thousands of participants from nearly every state in the US have grown single crystals of alum and sent them in to be judged. Winners receive cash prizes and a certificate. All crystal submissions go on permanent display in the Department of Chemistry at the Univeristy at Buffalo!

In 2017, the contest expanded and added the 'coolest crystal' category. Participants are challenged to grown the 'coolest' crystal possible while adhering to two rules: Nothing dangerous and the crystals will not be returned. This category really allows students to combine their remarkable creativity with the science of crystal growing. Notable entries include a glowing crystal (grown from a solution containing the ink from a highlighter), a 3D-printed Thanos glove with 'dyed alum' infinity stones, and and egg shell geode to name a few. 

The USCGC would not be possible without the support of the NSF and the incredible dedication and assistance from the regional coordinators (now known as the Crystallites!): Prof. Fernando Uribe-Romo (University of Central Florida), Prof. Karah Knope (Georgetown University), Prof. Michael Nippe (Texas A&M University), Tasha Benedict (University at Buffalo), and the countless graduate students from all of these groups!

 


Last Modified: 12/08/2021
Modified by: Jason Benedict
